properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The heat will persist until this evening. The combined values of temperature and humidity will give humidex values of 35 to 38. Limit physical activity; Drink lots of water, even before feeling thirsty, and keep cool. Check up on elderly family members, friends and neighbours. Make sure that they are staying cool and drinking water. Look for cool places, such as shade from trees, a swimming pool, a shower or bath, or an air conditioned location like a public building. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T23:10:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T15:11:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2593144213.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke is causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Poor air quality due to forest fire smoke is expected to improve by Wednesday morning when the wind changes direction. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If you, or someone in your care, develop symptoms, reduce strenuous outdoors activities where ever possible until the air quality improves. When outdoors, if your breathing becomes difficult or uncomfortable, stop or reduce strenuous physical activities. If you experience irritation of eyes, nose or throat, shortness of breath or other respiratory symptoms, you should take action to reduce your exposure to smoke. If you are feeling unwell and experiencing symptoms, contact your health care provider for advice. Issued jointly by Environment Canada and the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services. For more information on air quality and your health, please visit the Northwest Territories Department of Health and Social Services at www.hss.gov.nt.ca/en/services/environmental-health/air-quality. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-07-31T08:25:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services, 2019-07-30T16:26:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3692751096.2019
Area: Wrigley Region, Norman Wells - Tulita Region, Fort Good Hope Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:03 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2019-07-30T19:49:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T17:03:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1748410553.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain will continue today along with brisk northwest winds then come to an end this evening. An additional 15 to 25 mm is likely, bringing total rainfall amounts to 25 to 50 mm. This rainfall is associated with a low pressure system moving slowly northward over James Bay. Environment Canada's rainfall warning criteria is 50 mm in 24 hours or less. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T23:31:29-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass will remain over the Maritimes through Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures near 30 degrees will persist over much of New Brunswick today and Wednesday, with overnight lows near 19 C providing little relief. Humidex values of 37 to 39 will also persist. Maximum temperatures along the Bay of Fundy, will be somewhat cooler. However, areas slightly inland are still likely to reach heat warning criteria over the next two days. Temperatures across northwestern portions of the province will cool somewhat on Wednesday as a trough of low pressure begins to move across the region. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T07:58:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T15:59:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2748811470.2019

properties.Summary:

Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass continues to push into the Maritimes and will persist through Wednesday. Daytime highs over inland areas of Nova Scotia are forecast to be near 30 degrees today and Wednesday with overnight lows near 19 degrees providing little relief. Humidex values are expected to reach 36 to 39 today and Wednesday. Temperatures across the province should cool down somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wildfire smoke is causing poor air quality and locally reduced visibilities at times. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. For more information please visit Alberta Health Services at www.albertahealthservices.ca/news/air.aspx. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-07-31T08:21:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, Alberta Environment and Parks, Alberta Health, Alberta Health Services, 2019-07-30T16:22:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2602793314.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms are expected to form this afternoon and last into this evening. Some of these thunderstorms may become severe. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T04:26:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T16:27:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0777646057.2019

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Fog has moved into Sachs Harbour from over the Beaufort sea. Fog should remain until Wednesday when winds shift more westerly. There is the chance that fog may lift this afternoon before returning overnight. ### Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T09:10:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T17:11:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2239680306.2019
Area: Sachs Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will remain over the Maritimes over the next few days. Daytime maximum temperatures are expected to reach 30 degrees today and Wednesday. Overnight lows tonight are expected to fall to near 20 degrees providing little relief from the heat. Maximum humidex values of 35 to 38 are expected. Temperatures across the island should cool down somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T07:58:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T15:59:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4156147650.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 12:37 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts and up to nickel size hail. This severe thunderstorm is located near Cornwall, moving northeast at 65 km/h. This severe thunderstorm will be near: Cornwall around 12:35 PM EDT. Locations impacted include: Cornwall, Lancaster, Glenbrook, Williamstown, Summerstown and Bainsville. ### Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:25 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
